comments:
BPUB 250 introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a remarkably useful body of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. 

Students were divided in their opinions on the material covered in BPUB250. While many found it “useful” and “definitely valuable for upper level courses,” others thought that much of the material was “redundant” and covered topics addressed in ECON10, STAT, and OPIM. Several did note that the material covered in the second half of the semester was more interesting and useful. 

Professor Doherty was universally well liked, with many students ranking him among “the best professors I have had.” Others noted that they appreciated his humor and passion, which made them more interested in the lectures. 

Students complained that the fall section of BPUB, consisting largely of recent transfers into Wharton, has a much more competitive curve than the spring section and wished that that was addressed in future offerings.

BPUB 250 introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a remarkably useful body of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. 

Students were divided in their opinions on the material covered in BPUB250. While many found it “useful” and “definitely valuable for upper level courses,” others thought that much of the material was “redundant” and covered topics addressed in ECON10, STAT, and OPIM. Several did note that the material covered in the second half of the semester was more interesting and useful. 

Students tended to favor Professor Mitchell’s more structured lecture format, although a few found her to be more distant and unapproachable than Professor Doherty. Others also felt that her lecture slides could have been clearer. 

Students complained that the fall section of BPUB, consisting largely of recent transfers into Wharton, has a much more competitive curve than the spring section and wished that that was addressed in future offerings.

Students complained that the fall section of BPUB, consisting largely of recent transfers into Wharton, has a much more competitive curve than the spring section and wished that that was addressed in future offerings.

This course introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a remarkably useful body of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. 

Students were divided in their opinions on the material covered in BPUB250. While many found it “useful” and “definitely valuable for upper level courses,” others thought that much of the material was “redundant” and covered topics addressed in ECON10, STAT, and OPIM. Several did note that the material covered in the second half of the semester was more interesting and useful. 

Accolades poured in for Costa, who nearly every student felt was “one of the best TA’s I have ever had or even heard about.” They praised the clarity of his explanations as well as his preparation and determination to make sure that “everyone understood everything.” Others commented “he is just a wonderful person all around.” 

Students complained that the fall section of BPUB, consisting largely of recent transfers into Wharton, has a much more competitive curve than the spring section and wished that that was addressed in future offerings.

While many found it “useful” and “definitely valuable for upper level courses,” others thought that much of the material was “redundant” and covered topics addressed in ECON10, STAT, and OPIM. Several did note that the material covered in the second half of the semester was more interesting and useful.

This course introduces students to "managerial economics," the application of microeconomic theory to management problems. Microeconomic theory is a remarkably useful body of ideas for understanding and analyzing human behavior in a variety of contexts. 

Students were divided in their opinions on the material covered in BPUB250. While many found it “useful” and “definitely valuable for upper level courses,” others thought that much of the material was “redundant” and covered topics addressed in ECON10, STAT, and OPIM. Several did note that the material covered in the second half of the semester was more interesting and useful. 

Dizioli’s students found him to be a “great TA” who came “well-prepared” and “patiently answered anyone’s questions.” Some even felt that he “outdid the professors at times” and credited him with improving their grades in the class. 

Students complained that the fall section of BPUB, consisting largely of recent transfers into Wharton, has a much more competitive curve than the spring section and wished that that was addressed in future offerings.
